_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The management and employees of this facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia through the use of proper equipment, regular inspections, maintenance and training of all persons through the use of proper equipment, regular inspections maintenance and training if all persons that work with anhydrous ammonia.  Should any accidental release occur, this facility has worked with the local fire department and local emergency planning committee so they can plan for a response to a release and minimize the impact of the release to people and environment.



Facility Information:  The primary activity at this facility is the storage and handling of NH3 for sale to farmers.  NH3 is received, stored and distributed for direct application to the soil as a crop production nutrient.



Accidental Release Program:  This facility complies with the carious rules and regulations governing the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia (NH3), including ANSI K61.1, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111 and regulations administered by Illinois Department of Ag.  Training is provided on safe anhydrous ammonia operations for employees.



Worst-Case Scenario/Alternate-Case Scenario:  This facility has developed a worst-case and alternative case scenario, however, it has been withheld from the executive summary as security sensitive information.



Five Year Accident History:There have been no accdental releases of anhydrous ammonia for the covered process in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program:  This facility has a written emergency plan in accordance with OSHA Standards 29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.120 emergency planning and communithy right to know information is provided to the state emergency response commission, LEPC and local fire department as required by SARA title III of EPCRA.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Safety improvement is an ongoing process at this facility.  Periodic inspections and evaluations are performed to assess the main
tenance of safe practices an operations.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safey recommendations for implementation at this time.
